articles.title: Australia's strategy of denial in engaging with its ‘Pacific family'
articles.author: Wanning Sun
articles.summary: As Australia announces a historic defence pact with Papua New Guinea, it's clear that Australia sees the Pacific as a battlefield for control and influence. Few Pacific Island countries (PICs) like having to deal with political pressure from Beijing, and each has to navigate the tension between remaining friendly with Taiwan and accepting Beijing's largesse. Research shows that PICs choose to cooperate with China on certain fronts.

articles.title: Pakistan's climate reckoning for survival
articles.author: Riaz Missen
articles.summary: Floods have devastated Punjab and Sindh's floodplains, displaced 2.4 million people, killed 930 people and damaged roads, bridges, cropland and villages. Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's cabinet has declared a dual climate and agricultural emergency. The government is fast-tracking a 300-day National Climate Action Plan.

articles.title: Heatwaves deaths to soar as world warms, grim climate report warns
articles.author: Joseph Olbrycht-Palmer
articles.summary: Extreme heat is the leading cause of climate-linked deaths and hospitalisations in Australia. There were 354 deaths linked to extreme heat between 2001 and 2018 and 2000 hospitalisations between 2019 and 2021. The risk assessment warns that the figures could rise by 400 per cent in some capitals if temperatures are not kept under 3.0C. Even keeping temperatures lower will increase deaths by up to 200 per cent at 1.5C.

articles.title: Extreme weather could deal $611bn blow to property values by 2050: report
articles.author: Joseph Olbrycht-Palmer
articles.summary: Australia's first-ever climate risk assessment warns of a $611bn blow to property values by 2050. Coastal communities in northern NSW and Far North Queensland are most vulnerable to rising sea levels and bushfires. Heatwave-related deaths and hospitalisations are also set to soar as global temperatures rise.

articles.title: Heatwave deaths to soar in Australia as world warms, grim report warns
articles.author: Joseph Olbrycht-Palmer
articles.summary: According to Australia's National Climate Risk Assessment 2025, heat related deaths will spike with any increase to global warming. Even keeping temperatures lower will lead to significant surges, with 2.0C increasing deaths by up to 200 per cent and more than 100 per cent at 1.5C.

articles.title: Extreme weather could deal $611bn blow to property values by 2050: report
articles.author: Thomas Henry
articles.summary: Coalition accuses the Australian Climate Service of 'tilling the soil' for ambitious emissions targets expected to be set by the government later this week with its grim new climate risk assessment. The assessment claims extreme weather events would deal a $611bn blow to property values by 2050 and that increased global warming would cause a spike in heat-related deaths.

articles.title: How Gen Z is burning down the old order
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: The Global Sumud Flotilla was hit by an Israeli drone strike in Sidi Bou Said. Greta Thunberg's boat was destroyed by the drone strike. The flotilla is a symbol of Gen Z's fearless stand against goliaths.

articles.title: Strategy to avoid flood losses urged
articles.author: APP
articles.summary: Faisalabad Chamber of Commerce and Industry (FCCI) President Rehan Naseem Bharara has said that a comprehensive strategy is imperative to avoid heavy flood losses in future. Pakistan cannot afford such losses frequently, he said. PM Shehbaz Sharif has declared a climate and agricultural emergency. Field Marshal Asim Munir's recent statement underscored that Pakistan can't afford annual loss of lives and property.

articles.title: Kokua Line: Where are meetings on Hawaii's climate plan?
articles.author: Christine Donnelly
articles.summary: The Hawai 'i Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Commission is holding review sessions at public libraries across the state to collect feedback on the draft Climate Action Pathways. The online portal will accept public input through Sept. 30. The U.S. District Court of Hawaii keeps potential jurors' names on their active list every two years.

articles.title: Adapting to coastal erosion in Louisiana and Alaska
articles.author: Mallory Yu
articles.summary: Scott Detrow speaks with the team from the WWNO/WRKF podcast Sea Change about their reporting on community responses to climate-driven coastal erosion in Alaska and Louisiana and their work with the Sea Change team on climate change and coastal erosion. NPR's Scott Detrow is on the project.

articles.title: Adapting to coastal erosion in Louisiana and Alaska
articles.summary: An examination of community responses to climate-driven coastal erosion in Alaska and Louisiana is presented on On Air Now Playing News 88.9 KNPR Live, On Air Playing Classical 89.7 KCNV Live, and On air Now Playing KNPR Newscast.

articles.title: The Hottest Summer Days in D.C. Have Not Gotten Hotter in Last 40 Years
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: The coolest summer nights in Washington D.C. have warmed by almost 5 deg. F in the last 40 years. The urban heat island (UHI) effect has impacted reported warming trends. The most direct physical relationship to UHI warming would be the coverage of the area around the thermometer by impervious surfaces.

articles.title: Australia has a carbon 'budget'. It's due to be spent by 2036
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Unless Australia lifts its ambitions, its "fair share" of carbon emissions will be spent 14 years later than it was before.    .   "Australia's share of the carbon emissions bill will be 14 years higher than it would otherwise be.

articles.title: The higher our 2035 emissions target, the more necessary a carbon tax
articles.author: system
articles.summary: emissions reduction number is a laugh-or-cry-o-metre, or perhaps more accurately, a tax-o'metre.   Âng emissions reduction numbers.  yang emissions reduction. yang. yang. yang emissions.

articles.title: Farmers speak out after receiving low reimbursement checks for Helene damage
articles.author: WSOCTV.com News Staff
articles.summary: Farmers in western North Carolina are angry about the small reimbursement checks from the state's Agriculture Department to cover extensive crop damage caused by Hurricane Helene. The reimbursement checks are part of a $478 million Helene recovery appropriation from the General Assembly's Ag Disaster Crop Loss funds. A $221 million federal program was recently announced by the Department of Agriculture.

articles.title: The higher Australia's 2035 emissions target, the more necessary a carbon tax will be
articles.author: Alan Kohler
articles.summary: The key measure of success for the prime minister when he unveils Australia's 2035 emissions reduction target this week will be an absence of scorn. Countries that signed up to the Paris Agreement in 2015 agreed to submit five-yearly Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) for 2035. Australia's emissions reduction number is a laugh-or-cry-o-metre. Costa Rica hasn't even submitted its second NDC yet.

articles.title: The year Australia is due to blow its carbon budget
articles.author: Jake Evans
articles.summary: The world has a carbon budget between 2000 and 2050. Australia has a national carbon budget of 10.1 gigatonnes CO2-e between 2013 and 2050, which is about 1% of the world's carbon emissions. Australia emitted 4.82 Gt of CO2 from 2013 to 2023. On the current trajectory, Australia will have spent the entire carbon budget by 2036, 14 years early.

articles.title: World emissions hit record high, but the EU leads trend reversal
articles.summary: Human activities worldwide in 2024 sent a record 53.2 gigatonnes of CO2 equivalent (CO2eq) emissions to the atmosphere, without counting emissions from land use, land-use change, and forestry (LULUCF). This is a 1.3% rise compared to the previous year. The EU's GHG emissions shrank by 1.8%. The eight highest emitting economies collectively contributed to 66.2% of global GHGs. India has the largest increase with 164.8 Mt CO2eq more emissions released in 2024.

articles.title: Adapting to coastal erosion in Louisiana and Alaska
articles.summary: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with the team from the WWNO/WRKF podcast Sea Change about their reporting on community responses to climate-driven coastal erosion in Alaska and Louisiana. KAWC, PO Box 929, Yuma, AZ 85366, info@kawc.org, 877-838-5292.

articles.title: Australian bird of the year 2025: nominate your favourite now
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The Guardian/Birdlife Australia bird of the year poll will be held next month to choose shortlisted birds for the poll. Tell us which Australian birds you think should be shortlisted for the Guardian/ Birdlife Australia poll.   iReport.com.

articles.title: Kokua Line: Where are meetings on state climate plan?
articles.author: Christine Donnelly
articles.summary: The Hawai 'i Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Commission is holding review sessions at public libraries across the state to collect feedback on the draft Climate Action Pathways. The online portal will accept public input through Sept. 30. The U.S. District Court of Hawaii keeps potential jurors' names on their active list every two years.

articles.title: Extreme heat spurs laws meant to protect workers worldwide
articles.author: Somini Sengupta
articles.summary: This summer it was so hot in southern Europe that local governments in Greece, Italy and Spain ordered outdoor work to stop in the afternoons for several weeks. Japan required employers to protect workers from heat stroke risks or face $3,400 fines. Singapore requires employers to install sensors to measure heat and humidity levels every hour at large outdoor worksites and provide relief accordingly. Boston passed an ordinance this summer that will require all city projects to have a 'heat illness prevention plan' that trains work crews to spot heat illness and guarantees water and shade breaks.

articles.title: Anne Clarke on the London Fire Brigade's preparation for hot summers
articles.author: Anne Clarke AM
articles.summary: This summer has been Britain's warmest on record. There have been at least 64 wildfires in London this year. Long dry spells have left our open spaces parched. Fires damage property, threaten wildlife, and put lives at risk. Labour's lead for fire at the London Assembly is working with the London Fire Brigade to make sure they are ready. LFB is trialling new wildfire 4x4 vehicles that can drive over grasslands and "holey hoses" that create a wall of water.

articles.title: NJ Beaches at Risk? Congressman Pallone Warns of Massive Federal Funding Cuts
articles.author: Reed Becker
articles.summary: The Republican-led Energy and Water Appropriations bill for Fiscal Year 2026 includes just $15 million nationwide for beach replenishment projects. Congressman Frank Pallone, Jr. (D-NJ) has worked on a bipartisan basis to secure funding for coastal protection through the Army Corps of Engineers in his district.

articles.title: North York Moors wildfire hits merlin nesting sites
articles.author: Bill Teale
articles.summary: Britain's smallest falcon, the merlin, is making its way back to the coastal pastures and salt marshes where it willl spend the winter with other merlins from Iceland. Merlins spend the summer on the grouse moors, nesting on the ground among deep heather beds. The merlin is already Red listed as a bird of maximum conservation concern and rising temperatures caused by climate change will continue to pose a threat.

articles.title: The Arctic is heating up quickly, but scientists say polar geoengineering is ‘unrealistic' and ‘dangerous'
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: The Arctic is heating up. Scientists say polar geoengineering is 'unrealistic' and 'dangerous' and it's dangerous for the environment. CBC.    CBC. CBC,  CBC, and CBC, on "This is Life on Earth".

articles.title: This week in the Meeting Room, September 15-19
articles.author: Outer Banks Voice
articles.summary: This week in the Meeting Room, September 15-19, Outer Banks Voice has a list of events. Listings include Board of Commissioners Meetings, Town Council meetings, Planning Board meetings and Dare County Housing Task Force meetings. The meetings are open to the public and approved minutes from each are posted on this webpage.

articles.title: Labor will announce its 2035 emissions target this week. Here's how it could shape Australia's next decade
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Labor will announce its 2035 emissions target this week. Here are some of the ways it could shape Australia's next decade, as reported by The Guardian. The Guardian: Labor will announce this week its emissions target for the next decade.  The Guardian

articles.title: Australian bird of the year 2025: nominate your favourite now
articles.author: Guardian community team
articles.summary: The Guardian and Birdlife Australia are taking nominations for the 2025 Australian bird of the year poll. The winner will be announced on Thursday 16 October. Previous winners include the magpie (2017), the black-throated finch (2019), the superb fairywren (2021) and the swift parrot (2023).

articles.title: Climate inaction risks grave productivity slump
articles.author: Emma McGrath-Cohen
articles.summary: Insufficient action on climate change will lead to significant productivity losses by 2060, according to new research from Oxford Economics Australia. The economic research body will release the full details of its modelling next week. It has called for the government to look past short-term pain when setting emissions reduction targets.

articles.title: Climate change leads to more sugar consumption, study finds
articles.author: Madison
articles.summary: When the temperature rises, Americans drink a lot more sugary beverages and a few more frozen things. Climate change is shaping what you eat and how you eat. It might have a bad effect on your health, according to a new study by the University of California.

articles.title: Nova Scotia apple growers worried about their crops after extremely dry season
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Concerns are growing for farmers in Nova Scotia after an excessively dry season in the province, which is affecting farmers' livelihoods. The dry season has been especially bad for the last few years, especially for farmers' crops.

articles.title: Pakistan Floods: 2.5M Displaced, 101 Dead
articles.summary: Nearly 2.5 million people in Pakistan's Punjab province have been forced from their homes by recent catastrophic flooding. According to the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, extreme weather events displaced 43.1 million people internally in 2022. This number is projected to rise dramatically in the coming decades. Existing legal frameworks offer limited protection to those displaced by environmental factors. The concept of 'loss and damage' is gaining traction in international negotiations.

articles.title: We're going up in the financial world, but no one's noticed
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Australia may be on its way to becoming a 'switcher nation' – moving from a global debtor to a global creditor, as some analysts say.       .   in this way it could become a global financial powerhouse.  in the future.

articles.title: It's not even Fall yet. The birds are warning us that we're going to freeze our butts off this winter
articles.summary: Migrating birds have always shown up on radar. The birds don't know what's going on with the weather because of climate upheaval. The weather forecast is fuzzier than a herd of Labubu in an outbreak of St Elmo's Fire where I am.

articles.title: Blazing white stuff
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: It snowed in Canada in August for the first time since 2001. It was so hot in Canada this summer that it actually snowed. It is getting colder in some parts of Canada, but it is not snowing in the Arctic regions.

articles.title: As world gets hotter, Americans are turning to more sugar, study finds
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: When the temperature rises, Americans drink more sugary beverages and eat more frozen desserts. Global warming in the U.S. is amping up the country's sweet tooth, according to a new study. The United States' average annual temperature has gone up about 2.2 degrees since 1895.

articles.title: EA presents study on climate change impact on children
articles.author: Muskat Daily
articles.summary: Environment Authority has presented a pioneering study examining the impact of climate change on children and young people in the sultanate. The study is titled Climate Impact Analysis: Children and Youth in the Sultanate. It is an initiative to safeguard the next generation from the mounting threats of the climate change.

articles.title: Sindh govt fully prepared to tackle floods: CM Murad
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Murad Ali Shah is the Sindh Chief Minister. PPP Chairman Bilawal Bhutto Zardari has inspected the Guddu and Sukkur barrages. Water inflow at GUDdu Barrage has crossed 600,000 cusecs. Estimates suggest 650,000-700,000cusecs of water could pass through Suikkur Barrage. Since 2010 river embankments have been raised in height and current flood levels remain below the embankment line.

articles.title: Do the Feds Really Need to Own One-Third of All Land in America?
articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: The federal government owns about one-third of America. Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke wants to sell some of the land to reduce the debt. Environmentalists are opposed to selling the land, because they believe it will be destroyed by loggers and mining companies. The governors of Utah and Nevada also want the feds to release some land.

articles.title: 'I'm very disappointed': NC farmers shocked by low reimbursement checks for Helene crop loss
articles.author: Kimberly King
articles.summary: Farmers in western North Carolina are shocked at what they describe as tiny state Agriculture Department reimbursement checks to cover massive Hurricane Helene crop damage. The checks are from the legislature's Helene recovery appropriation of $478 million in Ag Disaster Crop Loss funds appropriated by the General Assembly. Randy Edmundson received a check for $5,151. Stuart Beam, a farmer in Rutherford County, suffered around $240,000 in crop losses with flooded acres.

articles.title: Nature Notes: It's the perfect time to view Hawks
articles.author: Annie Reid
articles.summary: September is the start of hawk-watching season. Migrating broad-winged hawks (Buteo platypterus) can be seen in the sky and in trees in local woods. Red-tailed hawks and Sharp-shinned hawks can also be seen.

articles.title: Is your house heating up and making you miserable? Paint it white
articles.summary: In 30 years time, the climate of London will feel like Marseille's today, according to Richard Schiano. He co-wrote The Architecture of Natural Cooling. The ancient techniques of white walls, shady courtyards and shuttered windows used in the Mediterranean are relevant for modern Britain. White surfaces reflect sunlight rather than absorb it, so painting roofs white can reduce internal temperatures by more than one degrees celsius and sometimes more than 4°C.

articles.title: Dr Karl Discusses Climate Change Insights at the Living Smart Festival
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: Dr Karl Kruszelnicki, Australia's beloved scientist, recently gave a presentation at the Living Smart Festival on the current state of our climate and what we can do about it. Dr Karl highlighted the alarming findings from the World Meteorological Association's State of the Climate in the South-West Pacific 2024 report.

articles.title: Record sea temperature in June and July: 2°C above historical average
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: The average sea surface temperature in Catalonia during this summer reached 25.8°C, the second highest since 1982. The temperature exceeded by 2°C the average historical temperature for June, according to data from the Catalan research institute on Sea management (ICATMAR).

articles.title: GFW = Great Fire Wall = 共匪网, 哈哈，笑死我了！好巧不巧？？？！！！
articles.summary: The Great Fire Wall is a wall of fire that stops people from attacking each other. It is made up of different pieces of wood and stone. It's made of different materials and materials and has different levels of thickness. It can be easily broken down into different parts.

articles.title: Climate adaptation: Students can bring a ray of hope
articles.author: Faizar Md Saolin
articles.summary: Bangladesh is one of the countries most vulnerable to climate change. The UN Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) and UNDP's Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC) project has engaged nearly 30,000 students across 291 wards in nine districts. In each ward, a platform has been created where local students are working to address climate-related risks. Ontu Rani, a second-year honours student, has been actively working for the past year to combat climate change in Char Montaz, an isolated island in Patuakhali district. In 2023, Ontu started a business called Sagar Konya Pure Dry Fish.

articles.title: Our 1000-year flood showed us the dangers of climate change
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: There was a 1000-year flood in Milwaukee this August. More than 85 of the nation's top climate scientists have pointed out the many errors in the report used to justify the Trump administration's Big Beautiful Plan to roll back safeguards to our quality of air and how we generate energy.

articles.title: Our 1000-year flood showed us the dangers of climate change
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: "Scientists: DOE climate report lacks merit" is the headline from the Sept. 3 paper. More than 85 of the nation's top climate scientists have pointed out the many errors in the report used to justify the Trump administration's Big Beautiful Plan to roll back safeguards to our quality of air.

articles.title: Hurricane force wind gust hit Wick during Storm Floris
articles.summary: August 2025 was Wick's warmest since 1997. It is currently the third most warm in a series commencing from 1910. August 2025 was the town's least wet since that of 2021 and the 39th driest since 1910. Summer 2003 is presently the warmest summer in Wick's history. The average daily maximum air temperature for August 2025 is 17.37C (63.27F) and the long-term average is 16.29C (61.32F). The highest daily maximum was 21.7C (71.1F), recorded on August 13 and the lowest outdoor ambient air temperature was 8.7 C (47.7F).

articles.title: The Junking of Science by the Climate Cult, As They Pretend to Be Able to Identify Exactly Who Is Creating Heat Waves
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: There is a recent study in Nature that claims that climate change made 213 historical heatwaves reported over 2000–2023 more likely and more intense. The authors used 1850-1900 as a comparison period to draw the contrast between 1850 and 1900. The period from 1850 to 1900 was generally colder than the 20th-century average.

articles.title: Smoke Paradox: Wildfires Could Improve Air Quality in the Eastern US, Study Finds
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: The heat from western US wildfires can improve air quality in the east by altering weather patterns and increasing rainfall, according to a new study. Iswi Singh is a content writer with a background in English literature. She worked as an editorial intern at Oxford University Press.

articles.title: Preventative maintenance you can take to reduce risk of winter house fires
articles.summary: It's the time of year when many homeowners start turning on their heaters and warming up the wood stove. Yukon's fire marshall shares some tips with CBC's Chris MacIntyre to ensure the only fire that happens this winter is in your wood stove, not in the house.

articles.title: In the Midst of Florida's Insurance Crisis, What Recourse Do Residents Have?
articles.author: Amy Green
articles.summary: Okeechobee, Florida, is home to some of the highest insurance nonrenewal rates in the state. It is also an overlooked epicenter of Florida's insurance crisis. Greenhouse gas emissions are heating the global climate, shifting weather patterns and leading to more extreme events such as wildfires and storms. Florida is uniquely exposed to rising seas and more damaging hurricanes.

articles.title: The Arctic is heating up quickly, but scientists say polar geoengineering is 'unrealistic' and 'dangerous'
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: In a new study, scientists say that polar geoengineering is a waste of time and money. The main proposals include artificially thickening sea ice, fertilizing the ocean with iron and releasing sunlight-reflecting particles into the atmosphere to reduce the sun's warming effect in the Arctic.

articles.title: The Arctic is heating up quickly, but scientists say polar geoengineering would cause 'severe environmental da
articles.author: Bridget Stringer-Holden
articles.summary: In a new paper, scientists say that polar geoengineering is a waste of time and money. The main proposals include artificially thickening sea ice, fertilizing the ocean with iron and releasing sunlight-reflecting particles into the atmosphere to reduce the sun's warming effect in the Arctic.

articles.title: Aussie Politicians want to Keep is Small if they Win the Bid to Host COP31
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Labor plans to cut numbers for UN climate summit. Albanese government will scale down the size of the COP31 climate summit to 30,000 delegates if its bid to host the conference is successful. If Labor wins the hosting bid, it will lobby to secure the event at this month's United Nations meeting in New York.

articles.title: Extinction Rebellion Protesters in Reading Barclays bank
articles.author: Olivia Endellion Mowl
articles.summary: The protest took place yesterday, Saturday, September 13. Extinction Rebellion is protesting against climate change and fossil fuel projects funded by Barclays Bank. Extreme weather is becoming more likely due to climate change. Heatwaves are the deadliest type of extreme weather globally, contributing to at least 500,00 deaths a year, including some in UK.

articles.title: Christopher Booker's 'The Real Global Warming Disaster' delves into the 'hockey stick' controversy
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: Christopher Booker's new book, "The Real Global Warming Disaster," delves into the 'hockey stick' controversy. He argues that the IPCC was established as a political organization to promote the idea of human-caused climate change and shape policy, rather than objectively assess the evidence. The IPCC's reports were crafted to present a strong case for the pre-determined view that global warming was caused by humans.

articles.title: As world gets hotter, Americans are turning to more sugar, study finds
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: When the temperature rises, Americans drink more sugary beverages and eat more frozen desserts. Global warming in the United States is amping up the country's sweet tooth, according to a new study. People tend to take in more sweetened beverages as the temperature gets higher and higher.

articles.title: Researchers make concerning discovery after tracking creatures in some of Earth's coldest habitats — here's what they found
articles.author: Rachel Beyer
articles.summary: Researchers tracked macaques in Kamikochi, Nagano Prefecture, Japan, from 2022 to 2024 using NHK footage and DNA from feces. They found that once daytime temperatures rose above freezing, the number of insect species in macaques' diets dropped. The monkeys stopped entering rivers as much, so their diet showed far fewer insect species. It's the second-warmest winter on record for Japan.

articles.title: Australia's Inland Waterways Have Doubled in Size Since 2019
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: The area covered by Australia's long-term inland water bodies has more than doubled since 2019. New technology means scientists are now able to view terrain down to the level of the terrain.       "The area of Australia's Long-term Inland Water Bodies has increased by more than double since 2019."

articles.title: Coastal barriers to debut in S'pore: How do they shield shores from extreme sea levels?
articles.author: Shabana Begum
articles.summary: The Republic plans to build three coastal barriers to protect Singapore's south-eastern coastline from rising sea levels by the 2030s. PUB has been studying the feasibility of installing coastal barriers near Jurong Island, Pasir Panjang Terminal and Tuas shipyards since 2023. Coastal barriers could also be part of the future Long Island reclamation project.

articles.title: Experts issue scathing rebuttal to US government report: 'A total disgrace'
articles.author: Susan Elizabeth Turek
articles.summary: Experts issue scathing rebuttal to US government report: "A total disgrace" They say it cherry-picks evidence, fails to be transparent, and lacks credibility. The Trump administration has made clear its commitment to the fossil fuel industry. It disincentivized many green energy projects that created jobs and lowered utility bills.

articles.title: Researchers make concerning discovery deep in Himalayas: 'This is clearly a signature impact'
articles.author: Alyssa Ochs
articles.summary: Gangotri glacier in the central Himalayas of India has melted by 10% over the past 40 years. The glacier provides water to the Ganga River in northern India and is a primary source of water for the communities in the region. Scientists studied the glacier system using actual and satellite data to conduct a modeling exercise. Global glaciers are experiencing similar effects because of human-caused climate shifts.

articles.title: Sharp drop in Gouldian finch sightings sparks worry in WA
articles.author: Jess Baker
articles.summary: The population of Gouldian finches in Wyndham, 3,300 km north-east of Perth in the East Kimberley has halved in the past year. The species was declared endangered in the late 1990s. The federal government is investigating whether the WA government has breached environmental conditions tied to protecting the nearby Ord Valley.

articles.title: As a dark chapter closes, NZ reckons with fugitive father Tom Phillips' four years on the run
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: The Phillips children lived with their father in a dark, grimy dugout in the middle of the freezing New Zealand bush. Childhood is measured in increments, birthdays, lost teeth, certificates, a felt tip on a height chart. In the case of the Phillips children, this increased the risk.

articles.title: Australia squeezed on climate by Vanuatu minister
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Vanuatu's climate change adaptation minister has urged Australia to stop fossil fuel exports. He says a recent climate change has been caused by the use of fossil fuels in Australia's energy supplies.      Â   in Vanuatu.

articles.title: New study finds disturbing side effect of rising temperatures on US families: 'Going to be a severe problem'
articles.author: thecooldown.com
articles.summary: A new study found a correlation between hotter temperatures and higher consumption of added sugars. "Climate change is shaping what you eat and how you eat, and that might have a bad effect on your health," said one of the study's co-authors.

articles.title: Council set to scrap 90-year-old carpet beating law
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Wirral Council is looking to repeal obsolete byelaws governing a stretch of Merseyside coastline. It wants to repeal "obsolete" byelaw governing the stretch of the Merseysidheside coastline, as it considers it is not relevant anymore.

articles.title: Skyline blue: A birdseye view
articles.author: Independent Australia
articles.summary: Bill McAuley's 40-plus-year news career began in 1969 as a cadet photographer at 'The Age' in Melbourne. He has several published collections, including 'Portraits of the Soul: A lifetime of images with Bill Mcauley'.

articles.title: Malta: The island where hunting rarely stops
articles.author: The Malta Independent
articles.summary: Bird migration is one of nature's great wonders, perfected over millennia. Birds travel thousands of kilometres across oceans, deserts and mountains. In Malta, they face a man-made gauntlet of hunters and trappers almost year-round. This is because of hunting and trapping.

articles.title: Can Lab-Grown Coral Restore Reefs Damaged By Climate Change?
articles.author: Slashdot
articles.summary: Coral reefs have turned ghostly white due to climate change. More than 50% of the world's coral reefs have been lost in the last 10 years, mostly over the past 10 years. "If changes don't change, the coral reefs will die out.

articles.title: From Vulnerability to Action: Why Bangladesh's Climate Vulnerability Index (CVI) Is a Game-Changer (UNDP - United Nations Development Programme Bangladesh)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Bangladesh is one of the most climate-vulnerable nations in the world. The risks are well-documented, but the tools to deal with them are limited.   (A K M Azad Rahman's article was translated from the original by A.K. Azad.

articles.title: S&P warns of reinsurer protections as catastrophe risks escalate
articles.author: Moneyweb
articles.summary: Global reinsurers scale back disaster risk even as climate change fuels more destructive events, as a result of the global warming trend.   .    "Climate change is increasing the risk of natural disasters"   for the reinsurers, as well as for their clients.

articles.title: Extraoordinary Human Impact on Animal Size Over 8,000 Years
articles.author: Ancient Origins
articles.summary: Archaeologists studied how human activities enlarged domestic animals while shrinking wild species over the past thousand years. Scientists from the University of California, San Diego, found evidence showing how humans enlarged animals and shrunk wild ones.       .  .

articles.title: Climate Change and African Development: Challenges and Opportunities
articles.author: Capital Ethiopia
articles.summary: Climate change is one of the greatest global challenges of the 21st century. Nowhere are its impacts more visible and severe than in Africa. Africa contributes less than 4% to global greenhouse gas emissions, but it bears a large share of the global burden.

articles.title: Addis Ababa Declaration: A New Climate Justice Path for Africa
articles.author: Capital Ethiopia
articles.summary: The Addis Ababa Declaration is a paradigm shift in Africa's journey toward climate resilience and sustainable development. It was forged at the Second African Climate Summit (ACS2). It has 157 action points and is not just political statements, but a statement of intent.
